values:
Star Trek: Miasma, Greg Cox. 

Hardly counts; more a diversion than literature, but comforting and familiar, like Grandma's mashed potatoes. In this one, Spock's blood is the only defense for a stranded away team on a foggy world full of giant, carnivorous leeches. Unlike Michener's Alska, mentioned in the last post, picking at this one during the occasional free moment between (or during other books) was no great challenge. There's no complex narrative thread to lose hold of...

Speaking of Alaska, I was surprised by the arrival of Star Trek: Elusive Salvation, a hot-off-the-presses forgotten pre-order. Set in the Arctic Circle c. 1845, San Francisco c. 2283 and New York c. 1970, it, too, was a purchase made when our own Artic adventure was imminent.  That part of its appeal no longer applies, of course. But I do like my mashed potatoes....

The North Water: A Novel by Ian McGuire.

Gripping.  Great sentences.  Grab the dictionary before reading for the occassional archaic term.  5 stars.

Am behind on my count because I started James Michener's Alaska - also engaging, like a good anthropology class- and got to the Russians' arrival before putting it down (not actually moving to Alaska has dampened my interests in its history).  I haven't met any recurring characters so can pick it up without too much trouble if I care to down the road.

Now on How to Talk Minnesotan by Howard Mohr (revised for the 21st Century).  Thanks, Chaddy, for the original.

Bazaar of Bad Dreams, Stephen King. Another delayed finish...started this months ago, but I guess the winter (such as it has been), not being conducive to commuting on foot, has seen a decrease in audio book consumption. But: Morality was powerful (and as a bonus: featured Queens), and the last one, Summer Thunder, which I just finished in a post-Poconos bath, was great straight-up sci fi.

Lathe of Heaven by Ursula K Le Guin. Amazing. Trippy. Transcendent. Michale Chabon says on the cover that he read it as a child and got so much more the second time around. So, into the book-you-should-have-read-in-school category it goes. Tonight, the British film version, courtesy of YouTube (and next week the DVD of the made-for-tv American remake with James Caan. Definitely will be re-reading someday soon. Next is the Michael Chabon's book-I've-been-meaning-to-read (it's been on my Kindle for years), Yiddish Policemen's Union. Set in Alaska, it's apropos for the day after Tj's epic convo with Kotzebue. (He's got the audio version in the car right now.)

Last night I finished In the Heart of the Sea: the Tragedy of the Whaleship Essex by Nathaniel Philbrick.  It was published in 2000 but is based on several firsthand narratives of the sinking and subsequent travails of the crew of Nantucket's Essex in the 1820s.  Although non-fiction, it was adapted by Melville for Moby Dick several decades later. I enjoyed the book, but then again I like everything about the sea...it was because of the 1,500+ piece Maersk cargo ship model that I got back into Lego, and my favorite vacations are cruises.  If I hit the jackpot tomorrow, the first thing I'm doing is buying a yacht (well, maybe I'll hire the seamen first).  Attached is a pic of what looks like a group of jaunty boys frolicking on deck...it's actually a screen shot (yay, Kindle!) of one of the illustrations from Heart of the Sea meant to convey the hardships of long ocean voyages (it's not giving away too much to say that cannibalism is a plot point).  I don’t think the movie version got great reviews, but I’m still excited to see it. (Although it was last year and won’t count for this challenge, as a sort of inoculation against spoilers I read the novelization of Force Awakens before seeing the film. Alas, these reverse adaptations don’t work very well and I wouldn’t recommend the “book.”) By the way, what the hell is 'salt junk'?? My quandary:  I'm not sure what category of the reading challenge this book falls in.  Closest I can manage is 'book previously abandoned' because I actually stated it last year.  But, it was December of last year, and it's only January now!   It’s like saying I "abandon" work every evening when I go home.  Anyway, suggestions appreciated. For my next book, I was going to read a recent translation of Madame Bovary, about an adulterous doctor's wife, as my 'book previously banned' (because of how tawdry it was for the time) but I didn't feel like schlepping a hardcover with me today (incidentally, it's #9 on this list of David Bowie's favorite books: http://www.nypl.org/blog/2016/01/11/david-bowies-top-100-books?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&utm_source=facebook.com&utm_medium=referral).  Luckily, Tj came back from a weekend visit to Oregon just last night and as a souvenir brought me back The Lathe of Heaven by Ursual K. Le Guin from Portland's famous bookstore, Powell's.   The endorsement on the front cover is a blurb by Michael Chabon (author of Yiddish Policemen's Union and Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay, among others), also introduced to me by Tj.  This one will be my 'book chosen by spouse.' Speaking of books, George R.R. Martin announced on his blog that the final installment of the Games of Thrones series would be delayed, resulting in the unusual phenomena of the television version actually preceding the source material.  His platform?  None other than LiveJournal.
I just watched about 6 hours of curiously curated episodes on Crackle in honor of the 25th anniversary.

Fuzzy moon through the blinds
In a sky that mirrors the deep
It's the angler fish's lure.

Staying off Twitter and Facebook to avoid Breaking Bad spoilers and using LiveJournal as my Internet outlet for the day. Btw, a very belated thank you to for a very funny YouTube spoof!

In other news, I'm in the lobby of the Greater New York Red Cross waiting for CPR/First Aid trainer class to start.

Also, have been pondering economics lately, in anticipation of the upcoming mayoral election, and have been wondering about whether wealth is relative, and how best to address income disparity and the growing divide between the lower classes and super rich. Admittedly, not my area of expertise, but curious to know wether anti-trust laws (or some equivalent) have ever been applied at the individual's level....

It finally occurred to me why the radio streaming app I listen to on my walk to work would conk out on me every now and then.  First, I deduced a pattern of occurrences, and initially ascribed those occasions to the the L.I.E. overpass which, I surmised, temporarily interfered with my reception.  Upon closer examination of my phone I realized that I was actually picking up a weak wifi signal from something called Miller's Ale House, where I had eaten once, and whose network I had apparently used.  As it happens, the internet service they provide customers is no better their food, and my interruption was caused by the switch from 3G, and back again, while moving through the restaurant's vicinity.      

I have a lot of time to think on my walk, and this is what I think about.

Gorgeous day for celebrating Garden Month and Poetry Month in New York. As part of the judging triad for Parks' "Garden of the Month" competition I get to explore horticultural wonders in all five boroughs, dressed in their seasonal best. Today marked the start of the 2013 season and the Bronx site happened to be Joyce Kilmer Park - his famous 'Trees' (I think that I shall never see / A poem lovely as a tree) was my Earth Day tweet - and appropriately enough, it featured a magnificent sculpture honoring Heinrich Heine, a German poet. The statue, whose details I hope can be discerned from the accompanying photos (note the hapless sailor's skull!), is a magnificent allusion to the 'Die Lorelei', or sirens, eponymous subject of his most famous work. An interesting aside: because he converted from Judaism, it took some doing, and significant financial support from the local German community, to finally get the statue placed in New York.

Also including a pic of some tulips from the surrounding flower bed because they're just too fabulous not to share!

Posted via LiveJournal app for iPad.

Walking on a street too new to ignore
unburdened by a coat,
the smell of front lawns infiltrate,
and words need juggling
like keys you no longer have
enough pockets for.

When wives tug trash cans back inside
because husbands are away,
or don't care,
the ordinary,
unfamiliar smell of houses
fills me like the strangeness of a friend's place
I was taken to play in,
made all the stranger 
for how un-notable it was
to the friend.

Those were the last days of boyhood,
and these, of a bachelor.

Smashed Snapple all over the floor; disgusting to look at, a danger to paws - but it's never smelled so peachy before. ~ I want to visit Kane, PA because a book I bought came stamped by their library last checked out in 1980

Traffic is bad when you keep pace with an ambulance while walking to work.  Sirens blaring and everything.  Every time I thought it had gone past, I'd catch up and see it stuck behind another jumble of cars.  Sirens still blaring.  I had to pause my audio book until I turned the corner:  am listening to The Shoes of the Fisherman, by Morris West.  Published 50 years ago, the story might as well have been ripped from today's headlines.  A new pope is elected and faces daunting challenges in the church.  Like Francis, he comes from afar: Ukraine (though in the story they constantly refer to him as "the Russian," because under the Soviets, all of the republics were lumped into one).  And while the issues of the day may be different -- the rise of communism and nuclear threat instead of globalization and sexual scandal -- all eyes turn to the pontiff for reform (but not too much!).  It's a fascinating story, and I'm eager to watch the Anthony Quinn movie version when I'm done.  From what I can tell, it's only available on video cassette, which is fine because, although I lost the clicker many apartments ago, my VCR's tape-playing function is perfectly intact.

I've been walking to work and listening to talk radio with an NPR app and some ear buds.  The microphone attachment allows me to answer the phone with the push of a button, located along the headphone wire, automatically pausing playback when I do.  During cold days, like today, I don't even take the phone out of my pocket to check the called ID; it's a throwback to the old days, when you never knew who was on the end other end of a ringing line.

Not long after we came to this city, my dad shook hands with him during a parade...he was our first mayor as Americans, and my dad always told that story with pride...it was quite a thing for a lowly immigrant to shake hands with the mayor himself...such a thing would never have been possible in the old country, and it was truly a sign of the amazing possibilities and advantages we could look forward to here.

I met him several times at various work functions...it was inspiring to be able to look up to a fellow gay (unconfirmed), Jewish NYer. RIP

I wish she'd post something...haven't heard from her in so long and have no idea what's going on!
...from the bf.  Alas, his life has been like the last season of LOST lately - a lot of going-back-to-the-island.

I saw Abduction today even though it only got a 4% rating on Rotten Tomatoes because it had Taylor Lautner in it.

I want to buy GLorry the $130 bottle of vodka i saw, the shape and size of a Gatling gun, complete with shot glasses and carrying case, as a wedding present. This isn't only because Gary nearly shot his finger off in a firing range mishap with my dad, but also because, though the ceremony they've asked me to perform, seven months early, in their living room, for insurance purposes, isn't exactly a shotgun wedding, it does seem to carry a similar sense of urgency.

I'm very frustrated with my job lately. I'm more artist and philosopher than mid-level bureaucrat.

The last of Suzanne's orange juice (she's away for a few more days, though...plenty of time to replenish).

A coffee, promptly handed to me with the proper fixin's by the bodega proprietor.  I had been enjoying my new eco-friendly ceramic mug by brewing my own for the past couple of days, but on Mondays I like to buy the paper rather then read online (breezing through the crossword makes me feel super smart) and I needed some smokes anyway, so I decided to just add the java to one big bulk purchase.  We chatted over the headlines (WikiLeaks again??) while I waited to check out.

One cigarette.

I want to be a whaler, but without all the killing.  Just sorta sail around on a big boat with lots of men.

I'm thrust back into early childhood, and am strictly obedient as a result, whenever walking past an intersection with a school crossing guard on duty.

I let my membership with the Socialist Party lapse.

Thanks!

I wish that LiveJournal wouldn't automatically include the date in every post; sometimes I'd like to use it as the the Subject when nothing else comes to mind.

If I ever write a book, I'd work very, very hard on a first sentence.  I often hear of works referred to by their first lines, and I figure, even if the rest of it sucks, my book can be recognized for that reason (plus, I'm much more liable to generate a successful sentence rather than entire book).  I'm toying with "Don't call me Igor."

As I was reading some Philip K. Dick last night I started wondering about space travel, and I came up with a theory:  society is in (and has been for approx. the last 100 years) a colonization lull.  This causes restiveness which manifests itself in war.  This is an extremely unscientific theory, as I am unschooled in history, warfare, or sociology.  But, it seems to (roughly) explain the little I do know.  Most of the conquest of the New World and Africa took place prior to the 20th Century.  The 20th Century was extremely bloody.  Is this accurate?  Dunno.  Did most exploration end by 1900?  Were previous centuries less/more/as bloody?  Dunno.  I figure if European colonization of the Americas started at around 1600, then yes, for all intensive purposes the continent was carved up by the modern area.  And between 2 world wars, the Cold War and the onset of the Era of Bush, the last one was a pretty intense century.  Yes, we don't often come by anything that remotely resembles the Inquisition or anything like that (plus, I saw Apacalypto...if Mel Gibson's right, there was some serious shit going on way before us), but nothing on the global scale we've experienced in recent decades.  Anyway, if it holds water, the predictive part of my theory states that once we start colonizing the rest of the solar system, we should experience more peace at home due to the common "Human" goal.

Today is my Grandfather's birthday.  Yesterday was Lynda's.  Tomorrow is my mom and Erin's.  I got my mom a kitchen blow torch and some creme brule ramekins.  She likes to cook, and I figure even if she doesn't care for it, it's practically hardware, so maybe my dad can use it.  Lots of birthdays this month...earlier in July was Chris Kelly's, a friend of a friend and LiveJournal buddy.  Late July is Jess's, an old friend and also LJ user (I wish I knew how to hyperlink to people's screen names...if anybody is interested in either of these two journals, please write me...I will talk you through accessing them, but be warned:  your computer must be set up exactly as mine is and have exactly the same buttons on it).  Mid-month is Scotty's, a high school chum of mine who I speak with every so often...I didn't know he had his own blog until recently and browsing through several years' worth of his entries today inspired me to update mine.

A very minor matter, and one that I wouldn't normally be concerned with (and wish I wasn't this time).  But, it's nagging at me slightly over the last day or so, and I thought some outsider perspective might prove helpful.

Last week I go out with a fellow.  I happened to have a spare ticket to an event which I acquired the day before it was for, the same day I happened to make the aquaintance of this guy through an online personals ad.  He seemed keen on going with me, so, while it was unusually hasty, our first date occurred just one day after we first started corresponding (that was Thursday).  We had a nice time, and saw each other again on Sunday (another nice date, or so I thought).

Now it's Wednesday, and like I said, my concern may be entirely over-exaggerated and insubstantial, but here's where it stems from:  as we departed from that second date, he casually mentions a possible dinner during the week, and promises to call on Monday.  That doesn't happen.  A phone message I left yesterday suggesting an evening activity tonight was un-returned.  Should I be worried?

He's in design, and the City is in high gear for Fashion Week, so busy-ness might be an impediment.  Plus, technically, it's not like days and days have gone by without contact, and when you factor in the fact that two outings in less than the space of week is above average for a new fling, it's very possible that this is standard and healthy just-started-dating-someone distance being imposed.

I'm not hung up on this guy, but would love to hear some thoughts on what's happening.  It could be nothing, but I've done my fair share of "forgetting" to call when I knew things weren't meant to be with particular person, so I'm familiar with the signs.

(Stolen from proko5)


1. Are you named after anyone? If so, explain.
My maternal grandmother's sister was named Ida.

2. Do you have your children's names picked out already? If so, is there any significance?
Forrest and Jenny, although the significance is not (solely) movie related.  Forrest for the obvious reasons, Jenny in honor of said grandma.  While "Zelda" was somehow arrived at as her legal English name, the closest transliteration of the original Russian is "Djzhenia."

3. If you were born a member of the opposite sex what would your name have been?
Not sure, but interesting story about my sister:  she was expected to be a boy, and Larry was chosen.  The spelling was barely changed, though, and hence her name means "English truck."

4. If you could re-name yourself what name would you pick and why?
Been there, done that.  My becoming a citizen at 6 provided a rare window of opportunity to legally change my name.  It was "Americanized" to Gary, with my original first name bumped into the middle name slot.  Suppose it was because Dif'rent Strokes was so popular at the time...

5. Are there any mispronunciations/typos that people do w/ your name constantly?
Sometimes I get two R's...sometimes I'm called Greg.

All in all, 30 wasn't terrible.  I still get carded for smokes, for instance...you can't beat looking 13 years younger than you are.

Taking stock of the past year:  Rufus came into my life, and for that I'm grateful.  I hit a momentous mark with my apt - I've now been there longer than the last three places I've lived, combined.  Got to see New Orleans; that was neat.  Also started a new job where I learned more about boozing and schmoozing that I ever thought possible...a nice little trick to have up one's sleeve.  And, I married off a bunch of friends.

Some resolutions:  Get back on the meditation track (once every day, even if only for 5 minutes).  Cook something new every week.  Attend a cultural event every month.  Quit smoking by the end of the year.

Thanks to all for another great year.

I lost my reading glasses last weekend.  I know it's just "stuff" and not really important in the grand sceme of things, but I was still a bit bummed about it.

It happened on my street...I've narrowed down the probable place of occurance to a stretch between two stores - one of which I remember handling them last, the next where I realized they weren't on my person anymore.  I scoured the sidewalk of the block, as well as asked at the two places if any had been turned in.  I suppose I could put up signs around the neighborhood, but it might be too late.

All in all not a total loss - my insurance covered some of the intial cost, and I did get a good half a year's use out of them.  But they were very fashionable - Calvin Klein frames - and I got a lot of compliments about them.

Oh well...not the end of the world.  I have a spare pair; I'll survive.

SONNET 73 
That time of year thou mayst in me behold 
When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang 
Upon those boughs which shake against the cold, 
Bare ruin'd choirs, where late the sweet birds sang. 
In me thou seest the twilight of such day 
As after sunset fadeth in the west, 
Which by and by black night doth take away, 
Death's second self, that seals up all in rest. 
In me thou see'st the glowing of such fire 
That on the ashes of his youth doth lie, 
As the death-bed whereon it must expire 
Consumed with that which it was nourish'd by. 
This thou perceivest, which makes thy love more strong, 
To love that well which thou must leave ere long.

I think this would be a great thing to do. 

Anybody interested should know that's it's a cool way of playing a part in an historic occassion, a pleasant diversion to occupy your time while your walking the dog or just getting some exercise (or, for some, a way of getting exercise in the first place), and a means for receiving neat prizes and giveaways.

It's only a committment of a couple of hours a week for a month or so and it's possible to sign up with a friend.

For those of you that don't know, I've recently been approved to begin work at another division of the Parks Dept.  I'll be leaving the Rangers, just two months shy of being awarded my 5 year pin.  My new work will be in the office of community relations at the agency's main headquarters, the Arsenal building in Central Park.  I'll be working directly for a woman who's basically the Parks Dept.'s social secretary and indirectly for the assistant commissioner for city-wide services, a man who I had worked for in my prior post as well, but now am closer to due to the removal of about 10 levels of the chain of command and incalculable reams of red tape.  I'll be in the same suite of offices as Kevin Jeffrey, the deputy commissioner for public programs, and just down the hall from the big man himself, Parks Commissioner Benepe.

Although I always loved being a ranger, I loved doing new things more.  My passion for exploring that particular world has been quelched, and now I must address my passion for all the variety that life has to offer.  I realize now that I will most likely never become an expert in any one field, but as long as the jobs I take are as intersting as they have been (trail guide, fondue maker, physics teacher, park ranger, officiant, and now, event planner) I will remain content.  In fact, I feel revitalized that I've succesfully made this move, proving the fact that you don't have to get stuck and exploration is always an option.  I've only began, I realized, to scratch the surface of everything I want to do in my life (personal chef, professional actor, theologian, etc).

I'm leaving the wonderful world of being a grown-up-boy-scout and curator of the the country's greatest living museum without any regrets, but not, alas, without some saddness and sense of nostalgia.  I had a great time and have done some pretty neat things: I've fished, rock climbed, backpacked, biked, birdwatched, canoed, ice skated and sledded.  I've met Rudy Guilliani, Donald Trump, James Earl Jones, Cynthia Nixon, Kitty Carlisle, Candace Bergen, etc.  I helped weigh the worlds largest ice cream cake at Union Sq. Park for Guiness, ushered in countless thousands of runners at Tavern on the Green during five consecutive NYC Marathons, marched in the St. Patrick's Day Parade, was in numerous news programs and print aricles for a variety of animal rescue related incidents, and had an audience with Christo and Jeanne-Claude on the eve of their project in the park.  I found out that penal law (sadly) isn't what I had pictured in my mind, and learned how to do the Georgia State take-down with a PR-24 baton.  Perhaps most importantly, I'll be forever grateful for the the chance I got to assist in recovery efforts at Ground Zero.

I want to thank those who've aided me along the way and put up with my rants and raves about city gov't.  I will miss most being able to drive you guys around in golf carts and pick-up trucks, let you into off-limit buildings to use bathrooms, lounge with you on the Sheep Meadow during lunchbreaks, dine al fresco on the terrace of the Castle after closing and take you on rambling tours of the Ramble. 

Now, time to shop for business casual!

My grandfather is 88 and has not been doing so well.  He's been in the hospital for a few days now, practically paralyzed on his entire right side after a recent stroke - the most recent of several, apparantly, that had gone undetected over the last several months.  He's unable to communicate much beyond simple yes or no answers, and that's when he's cognizant enough of the questions.  

My mom wistfully asked me during our visit today about avoiding old age.  I told her, of course, that it's inneviatable, but the trick to dealing with the demise is to make a difference while still young.  To bear death, live a meanigful life.  She said I seem to have cheated time by doing better than most staying young; at a recent family gathering I frequently was paid the compliment of not having aged at all in a good number of years.  My "success" is superficial.  My grandfather, on the other hand, was a veritable force of nature in his younger days (which is not too many ago).  When my grandmother died in '93, his own decline bagan.  Before that though he -and she, till the very end- shaped my like few other individuals can.  He is the last of 4 siblings that made a great family.  The oldest, the only daughter, died long before my time, but the three brothers founded branches of my family tree that still thrive today.  Indeed, that gathering was an example of a regular celebration of their legacy.  In this instance, the occassion was a wedding of a member representing the third generation since those World War I era boys were born.  One settled in Toronto.  He too died before I had much opportunity to get to know him, but tales of him taking his own life are still whispered.  My grandfather's other brother, a jovial fellow who I used to get a kick out of seeing the few times he'd come over from St. Paul because of the intense resemblance (as a child, with your entire world made up of so few, it's astounding to meet such a close match of an promiment player), died about 15 years ago in a roofing accident.  The matriarch of the clan was Dora, a woman I had the privelage and pleasure of knowing for many years.  She passed at well over 100, and still it was untimely.  My grandfather is the only child to have outlived her.

My grandfather won't be going back to live in his apartment; arrangements are being made for a nursing home.  I pray his suffering be minimal, and my mother's burden bearable.

So, I got back from the Caribbean yesterday where I sailed to celebrate my cousin's marriage along with 50 other relatives/friends (and about 3,000 strangers, including crew).  The only other cruise I had ever been on was decades ago and so don't remember much about it.  Here are some interesting recollections about this one:

A boat in the middle of the open waters is my ideal vacation, I've come ot realize.  Especially a luxury liner - they wait on you hand and foot and you can do nothing for 24 hours a day is want.  The stuff there is to do they keep mindless enough so that you're still not really exerting too much energy.

You'll gain about 7 pounds a day sailing this way.  For a skinny guy like me it's a very acceptable part of the bargain.  There are about 7 full scale restaurants on board, room service, plenty of fast-food bars, two buffets...the options are pretty endless.  One night during the evening of the actuall wedding (which happened on St. Thomas in one of the oldest synagogues in the New World), we were served a 10 course meal.  I tell you, that's living.  The food did not stop being shovelled into our mouths.

The staff is super friendly.  Also very international.  Some one from a developing country can make enough on an 8 month tour to put on a down payment on a house upon their return.  But, they work 7 days a week (that's 8 months without a day off!!).  Pretty wacky, but I guess you do get to travel a lot and there are no expenses for you while you're there.  The casino and gift shops are the key jobs apparantly...at ports of call they must be closed acording to international law so those employees get extra time off.  Anyway, they are soooo nice to you there.  Our stateroom steward seemed to be on duty 24/7.  I had but to peek my head out of the cabin and he'd appear ready to help in whatever way i needed.  Everything was 'yes, Sir' and 'no, Sir.'  Even the senior doctor on the ship was as polite to me as the lowliest junior waiter.  We happened to run into him on the elevator as we were heading up to the night club on the last day.  He was very identifiable as a crew member beacuse they al have to wear their unforms even while off duty.  Beofre having read his name tag though and realizing his rank, we asked for a tour of the engine room, which we had been interested in seeing from day one (I went on a galley tour earlier in the week, but it left much to be desired).  Although he said it wasn't possible, he was extremely appologetic - said even most of the crew compliment can't go down there (actually, what caused a little chuckle was that he first asked if we were engineers ourselves).  The point is, even  my own doctor isn't as nice to me as he was!

Getting around was kinda tricky at first.  I'm not a natural navigator, so there was a lot of referring to the little "you are here" placards all over the place.  And asking for directions (which couldn't be simpler since no matter where you looked there was crew around - 1 to 2 crew/passenger ratio, I believe).  I still can't keep port and starboard straight, but eventually I got the hang of being able to tell if I was going forward or backwards on the boat by looking overborad and seeing the direction of the water moving.  I also realized that an additional ammenity they could add is moving sidewalks.  There were penty of elevator bays (the ship had over 20 stories) but is was moving along any one deck that gave you your exercise for the day.  And speaking of moving, the rocking takes about a day to get used to.  (Riding the NYC subways as practice beforehand helps).  When you get drunk, your stumbling kinda cancels out the ships motion). 

Getting drunk happened all the time.  I think I had a buzz going literally the entire time there, including sleep.  Drinks by the pool, wine tastings, cocktails with dinner, some sort of cray evening activity like a champage water fall or something, then rounds of shots at the dance club.  The whole things starts again in the morning.  My one uncle from Minnesotta runs a liquore store and brought a whole supply of alcohol with him.  He'd order pitchers and pitchers of juice with breakfast (it was included with our meals in the morning but cost extra throughout the rest of the day) and we'd have cranberry and vodka or screwdrivers till it ran out.  While laying and getting tan you might stir awake long enough to see a deck attendant delivering a tasty looking drink to someone...you'd order the same.  This went on and on.  On the beach of Tortola in the British Virgn Islands we drank some of the local beer.  Once on San Juan we went to some sort of chain restaurant called Senior Frogs (a spring break staple it seems) and had two foot high Long Island Iced Teas (a little taste of hime :-)

On the last full day we were supposed to stop by an island of the Bahamas, but the weather was too rough.  This little island was owened by Princess and you had to get on smaller boats while the Star Princess was anchored off shore and the high winds didn't permit that.  I took the opportunity of another day at sea to have a massage.  Very special (not as good as Chadwick, of course). It included a rest on a hot rock bed afterwards, an aromatherapt sauna and a tropical rainforest mist shower.  Other activities throughout the 7 days were:  jet skiing, snorkeling, hot tubbing, golf chipping, movies, shopping, comedy and magic, and, an all male wet t-shirt contest (and that's not an exhaustive list).

Being with my family was ok, I guess.  Ronnie, the groom, is a nice enough fellow.  He's from Montreal and I got to meet a lot of other French-Canadians.  It was also nice to see my side of the fam.  (of cours there was much drama, but would a reunion be without a little?).  Lorry and I shared a cabin, so we have to not see eachother for a few months now.  My beatiful aunt Laura is on Prozac, so was on cloud nine the whole time (even able to put up with her 80 y/o mother who wouldn't leave her side) and was a pleasure to be around.  Her son, Larry, won 1,500 gambling.  Rita, Bernice's (the bride's) sister brought her two boys who I had not met yet, so I got to do that. 

Right now I'm actually feeling a bit under the weather.  I suppose I should be glad I didn't get sick until the end of the stay, but I hate flying with a cold and hate not being able to fully enjoy the one day I have free between coming back to NY and having to return to work Tuesday.  Erik came by to see me yesterday and I felt back that I wasn't up to the welcome home celebration we had both been envisioning. That's all folks.  Sorry for the spelling errors, I'm in a DayQuill trance.
